title: On the Q-Factorization of Power Series.pdf
abstract: . Any power series with unit constant term can be factored into an inﬁnite product of the form Q n≥1(1 −qn)−an. We give direct formulas for the exponents an in terms of the coeﬃcients of the power series, and vice versa, as sums over partitions. As examples, we prove identities for certain partition enumeration functions. Finally, we note q-analogues of our enumeration formulas. In honor of George Andrews and Bruce Berndt for their 85th birthdays 1. Introduction and main results Many major results in number theory, analysis, and combinatorics take the form of “a series equals a product”; in particular, the use of product-sum generating functions is a prevalent method in partition theory. In [1, p. 98, Ex. 2], George E. Andrews considers the factorization of an ordinary power series with unit constant term into a q-product: (1) 1 + ∞ X n=1 r(n)qn = ∞ Y n=1 1 (1 −qn)an . Andrews suggests a recursion by which the r(n) can be calculated from a given sequence an, namely (2) nr(n) = n X j=1 r(n −j) X d|j dad. The reverse problem, where the r(n) are given and the an are calculated recursively, is given by David Bressoud [3, p. 61, Ex. 2.3.10]: (3) nan = Dn − X d|n d<n dad, where Dm = mr(m) − m−1 X j=1 Djr(m −j). Date: February 3, 2025. 2010 Mathematics Subject Classiﬁcation. 30B10,11P81,40A20. Key words and phrases. Power series; inﬁnite product; integer partitions. 1
